question.title: Set placeholder in a String "equals" check
question.body:
I've got two lists in my Java app: The first contains commands, the second the according valid replies, which I compare to the actual replies:

private final String[] commands = {"Do something","Do something else","Do a third thing"};
private final String[] replies = {"Step is done: 123,345","+OK","Process X finished"};

for(int i=0;i<commands.length;i++) {
    sendCommand(commands[i]);
    String reply = receiveReply();

    if(reply.equals(replies[i])) {
        System.out.println("Success!");
    } else {
        System.err.println("Error: "+reply);
    }
}

The "X" in the last reply can be any number. Probably <100 but I don't know it in advance (it's sent by an external program that I don't control). I currently also don't care what number it is.

What I want to do: Check the validity of the last reply but ignore the number.

I'm aware that I can just do something like this:

if(i==commands.length-1) {
    if(reply.startsWith("Process") && reply.endsWith("finished") {
        System.out.println("Success!");
    }
} else {
    //Regular checks ^
}

This however requires the extra "ugly" check of i.

Is there any kind of placeholder (e.g."{{X}}") that I can use to ignore that part? I know of regex of course but I've got pretty much no experience with it. I found this answer that uses (.*) to search for two placeholder texts in a String and I know that ^[0-9]*$ matches any number, so I could combine these to match the last reply but that would still require the extra if. This becomes more complicated because almost every reply contains at least one special character, like a comma, colon, plus sign or quotation mark (I know that regex uses at least +).

How do I use the same "clean" check for every reply, including the last one? Is this even possible with just basic Java 8?

answers.body:
You could use a regex-based approach like you suggested. Instead of an array of Strings, use an array of Patterns (i.e. regexes).

For strings that you want to match literally, use Pattern.quote to create a "literal" regex. For everything else, write an appropriate regex to match the desired text.

private static final Pattern[] REPLIES = {
        Pattern.compile(Pattern.quote("Step is done: 123,345")),
        Pattern.compile(Pattern.quote("+OK")),
        Pattern.compile("Process \\d+ finished")
};

The if condition can be changed to

if(REPLIES[i].matcher(reply).matches())

An alternative to a Pattern array is List<Predicate<String>>. You can write exactly what you want the if condition to be for a given reply using a lambda expression.

private static final Pattern THIRD_REPLY_PATTERN = Pattern.compile("Process \\d+ finished");
private static final List<Predicate<String>> REPLIES = Arrays.asList( // use List.of(...) on Java 9+
        s -> s.equals("Step is done: 123,345"),
        s -> s.equals("+OK"),
        s -> THIRD_REPLY_PATTERN.matcher(s).matches()
);

The if condition would test the predicate

if (REPLIES.get(i).test(reply))

question_comments.body: @Gimby It is the easiest solution but I don't like singling out certain is because not only does it make the code messier imo but it can also lead to "hm, might as well do this for command x", instead of trying to find a solution that works with any command.
I read somewhere else that performance is a concern. Given that constraint I find the if(i == bla) condition absolutely beautiful.

@C3roe That would be an object with a String (not an actual Pattern) and a boolean, correct? Interesting solution. It does add an extra check but all replies are still treated equally in a way that it doesn't matter what their i is, so I wouldn't mind that. As Rob Spoor has pointed out, creating regex is performance heavy, why not save the pattern as Pattern and check if it's null, then use the regular String if it is?

"or how would you decide what has to be treated as a regex and what doesn't?" - like I said, by explicitly storing that information as well. Would need some different data type, than just a list of plain strings - for example a list of objects, where one property is the pattern, and the other one is patternIsRegex with value set to true or false.
@Yousaf There's always going to be a number, which is probably <100 (that's what multiple tests have shown).

@C3roe My reason to use arrays, not nested over nested ifs, is that I wanted a clean solution that works with any reply and even allows me to skip commands (the order in which commands are sent is important). What would your solution look like or how would you decide what has to be treated as a regex and what doesn't? I'm guessing there is no general "ignore this part" symbol for checks then?

".+ matches anything" - yes, the dot character matches anything. If the last reply isn't guaranteed to have a number between the text (as shown in your example), then you can replace the dot character with \\d ---> Process \d+ finished

In addition to what @C3roe stated: if you decide to treat everything as a regex, you can use the \Q and \E escape sequences or Pattern.quote() to convert a string literal to a regex. That would give you something like private final String[] replies = { Pattern.quote("Step is done: 123,345"), Pattern.quote("+OK"), "Process [0-9]+ finished" };
@Yousaf Just tried it on regex101: .+ matches anything, not just e.g. "12" but also "ab".

"but that would still require the extra if" - if you don't want to give one of the items special treatment, then you need to give them all the same treatment. Meaning here, use regex for the validation of all replies, not just a particular one. Or, have your data structure also contain the information, whether the reply is supposed to be verified by string comparison, or regex. Then you'll still need an if/else to decide which one to apply - but the necessary info will come from within your data structure itself, so you don't need to make this dependent on the position of the reply.

79785252.body: @user85421 Is there a shortened version for this too?

@Neph '"Process \\d+ finished"::matches, is that the same thing?' - I do not think so - the method is String.matches(String) so the compiler does not mind you swapping argument and receiving object (this); but the argument is the regular expression - opposite as wrote in that code
@RobSpoor - sometimes readability is more important.... and if you re-use the Matcher, as I also suggested if performance is important, the Pattern will not be re-created
@RobSpoor Ah, I see. Is there a shortened version for the static THIRD_REPLY_PATTERN version too?

@RobSpoor Weird, can't reply directly, hopefully you'll still see this: Thanks for the warning, not being thread-safe is a problem because all the checks are happening inside a Runnable's run. Sweeper's version it is then. Theoretically performance shouldn't matter because of the threads but in reality I don't know how many of them are going to be started, so it's not a bad idea to still be a bit careful, especially since I am using a semaphore because data has to be shared between the main class and the threads.

That's the inverse: it will treat that string literal as the string to match, and the argument as the regex. It's the same as s -> "literal".matches(s). And replacing an explicit Pattern with String.matches is never an optimization, as the latter creates a new Pattern for every invocation.

The following is not thread-safe (Pattern is, Matcher isn't), but it would look like this: private static final Pattern PATTERN = Pattern.compile("..."); private static final Matcher MATCHER = PATTERN.matcher(""); for the declarations, then MATCHER.reset("actual string") and MATCHER.matches()

@user85421 String,matches always creates a new Pattern, and should therefore only be used if the regex is dynamic. If it's fixed, always create a private static final Pattern constant and use PATTERN_CONSTANT.matcher(s).matches() instead.

test just delegates to the backing method reference / lambda. So a predicate created from "my string literal"::equals (or alternatively, s -> "my string literal".equals(s) will be almost as performant as calling .equals directly. You'll have to perform millions of calls to see the difference. Likewise, MY_PATTERN_CONSTANT.asPredicate() will be almost as performant as calling MY_PATTERN_CONSTANT.matcher(s).find(), because that's what's being called. If you need matches then use s -> MY_PATTERN_CONSTANT.matcher(s).matches()
@user85421 This new comment section is confusing... No pre-compile but use it directly? My IDE doesn't complain about "Process \\d+ finished"::matches, is that the same thing?
@Neph - just a slightly optimization instead of THIRD_REPLY_PATTERN.matcher(s).matches() (like replacing it by s.matches("Process \\d+ finished") )
@Neph Ah actually you can write "Step is done: 123,345"::equals instead of s -> s.equals("Step is done: 123,345").
@user85421 What would this look like?
@Sweeper Sounds good, thanks! I'm guessing there's no way to shorten the s -> part a bit?
@Neph Calling test runs what you put in the lambda expression, so for the cases where you match a string exactly, it would do exactly the same thing as equals.

@Sweeper Okay, not exclusively using Regex would be better then because I've currently got more than 10 commands and only the very last one needs special treatment. Thanks for posting an alternative! How does test perform compared to equals?
btw. String has a matches(String) method, but if performance matter (that much,) then Matcher has a resset(String) so it can be re-used instead of being re-created
@Neph I have also added an alternative to using regex for everything.

@Neph Yes, matching regex is a lot heavier than equals. If you are worried about performance you can write the matching logic as a lambda expression and put it in a Predicate<String>[]. And correct, you don't need to escape anything extra. Pattern.quote takes care of escaping.
Thanks for the suggestion! So there's no need to escape anything in the "literal" regex that you don't already have to escape in regular Java?
@RobSpoor Performance was indeed another concern and what I already wanted to ask about. Is matches a lot "heavier" than equals?

Compiling regexes is a relatively heavy operation. I suggest turning the array into a private static final Pattern[] REPLIES field, so the regexes only need to be compiled once. Other than that, great answer!
